cards.calloutText: The Interhacktives (my students on the MA Interactive Journalism at City, University of London) live-covered the launch event for Media Moments 22.
Download your copy of the report here.

sections: I‚Äôve had access to an advance copy since last night, and here are my highlights:
Ad volume reductions mean a better user experience
This is an interesting observation about decreasing ad volumes on some pages:

At the Press Gazette‚Äôs Future of Media Technology Conference both the UK‚Äôs Independent and Telegraph newspapers said that they have been reducing the number of ads appearing on their web pages. Increased regulatory scrutiny and the threat of tighter privacy rules contributed to the moves. But concerns over user experience are at the heart of the shift. The Independent‚Äôs chief data and marketing officer, Jo Holdaway, said that putting less ‚Äòweight on the page‚Äô improves site performance and respects user data.
I suspect the motivations are different here.
has moved to a membership model, and so is motivated to increase reader experience by decreasing ad load.

, on the other hand, is still largely ad-driven. My suspicious soul suggests to me that this might be more to do with the penalties Google now applies for a shitty ad-driven user experience, and a desire to recover from them.
Newsletters are at the centre of a local news renaissance
Local newsletters are the foundation stone of a reborn local media:

6AM City co-founder Ryan Heafy told Media Voices in March that they had reached 1 million newsletter subscribers across the 24 cities they covered, and were on track to exceed $10 million in revenue this year. That‚Äôs pretty good going for a 6-year-old hyper-local business.

And there are other examples in that section of the report. If somebody gave me a bunch of cash to start a local title today. I‚Äôd absolutely start it as a newsletter with an accompanying web presence, and see search and social as vital acquisition channels for acquiring new newsletter subscribers.
And I‚Äôd build it on Substack or Ghost because there‚Äôs no justification for building your own tech and subs stack when those two are both driving forward so fast.
And B2B should be taking them seriously, too.
25 years ago, a good proportion of the paying readers of
, the original name for the online version of
, saw their sub as buying them a twice daily newsletter. A
later, people are still failing to learn that lesson.
, one of the early innovators in the new wave of newsletters, is slowly waking up to it, abandoning its paywall in favour of more focus on its newsletters.
CEO Zach Seward explained: ‚ÄúWe found that 75% of Quartz members read us primarily through email, so we‚Äôve been putting more of our best stuff directly in their inboxes.‚Äù
The jury‚Äôs still out on newsletter as a renovation technique
Interesting to hear how things are going at

Recent reporting has described initial subscriber acquisition targets as ‚Äòtoo ambitious‚Äô and The Atlantic is said to be reassessing its position. However, Nicholas Thompson has said the company will extend the contracts of its newsletter writers until they develop a better understanding of the impact newsletters have on subscriber retention.

But new forms of feedback are emerging in a post-open rate world

People are still clinging to open rates as a core metric for newsletter, but Apple‚Äôs changes mean that most open rates are now, basically, a lie. Anyone using an Apple device with email tracking protection turned on looks like they open your newsletters as soon as they get it ‚Äî even if they never really open it.
I‚Äôd argue there‚Äôs still some value in looking at variance in open rate, but we clearly need more than that. And that‚Äôs what the

To maximise response rates and make survey results as useful as possible, they created a one-click feedback mechanism embedded at the bottom of the newsletter, letting readers give feedback as they finished reading. This rated satisfaction on a scale of one to five and was used as the basis for an overall satisfaction score of -100 to +100.
Those of you who got this post via email can do a more primitive version of that and the end of the email‚Ä¶
I first wrote about the potential of paid podcasts, based on China's experience ‚Äî
. But now it‚Äôs here in the western world‚Ä¶

Tortoise, for instance, is using Apple Podcasts‚Äô Subscriptions tool to allow users to gain access to gated podcasts ‚Äì without paying for a full membership10. It is a more considered approach to using audio, one that doesn‚Äôt simply rely on pointing at huge audience numbers.

It‚Äôs a fact that people react to things that trigger emotions in them on social media. The more reaction, the more signals to the algorithm that this is ‚Äúgood‚Äù content, and so the more it spreads. But this has gone rather wrong in journalism:

Feeding the outrage engine with emotive headlines in pursuit of short-term traffic gains is having a negative long-term impact on the media‚Äôs ability to engage with audiences. It is also adding to the polarisation that has defined public debate recently; another major reason given for news avoidance (17%) was that discussing the news stoked arguments.
This is what happens when the horrible old maxim ‚Äúif it bleeds, it leads‚Äù meets social media. Folks, let‚Äôs start experimenting with emotions that aren‚Äôt just outrage‚Ä¶
And one sentence I disagree with
The larger organisations fell into the digital publishing trap of SEO and clickbait, which has degraded the quality of the audience.

C‚Äômon now. SEO at its best is about identifying a reader need for information and delivering on that need. Lumping it in with clickbait without any sort of qualifier is doing a fundamental audience engagement technique a massive disservice.
